title: State v. Alex Rivera â€” Emergency Laptop Borrowing
story: Alex Rivera, a third-year engineering student, borrowed roommate Eli Chen's laptop without permission after Rivera's device died minutes before a proctored exam. ProsecutorBot-03 filed charges for unauthorized access, arguing Rivera breached the shared-housing conduct code. The defense claims the emergency justified the temporary use and that Rivera immediately informed Eli afterward.

defendant.name: Alex Rivera
defendant.title: Engineering Student (Defendant)
defendant.summary: Pleads not guilty, citing academic emergency and intent to replace any wear on the laptop.

prosecutor.name: Jordan Hale
prosecutor.title: Student Conduct Prosecutor
prosecutor.summary: Frames the borrowing as a consent breach that undermines shared trust agreements.

defenseCounsel.name: Morgan Lee
defenseCounsel.title: Defense Advocate
defenseCounsel.summary: Insists necessity doctrine applies because Rivera faced academic failure without the device.

charges: Count 1: Unauthorized use of personal property
Count 2: Breach of roommate technology agreement

timeline.event: Rivera discovers laptop battery failure moments before the exam.
Rivera unlocks Eli's laptop using the shared password to join the exam portal.
Exam concludes; Rivera wipes browsing history and sanitizes the keyboard.
Rivera texts Eli admitting the emergency borrowing and offers to run diagnostics.

evidence.label: Housing Agreement
evidence.detail: Signed contract requiring consent before sharing electronics.

evidence.label: System Logs
evidence.detail: Login records showing a 78-minute session under Rivera's credentials.

evidence.label: Message Thread
evidence.detail: Screenshots of Rivera notifying Eli immediately after the exam.

juryBox.stance: Jury Box leans toward a policy breach but recognizes mitigating academic pressure.

comments.text: Consent is the cornerstone of shared housing; Rivera bypassed it entirely.
Emergency necessity doctrine applies. Rivera prevented exam failure and caused no damage.
Box tally: 7 votes to reprimand, 5 to forgive. Crowd sees a breach with compassion.
Why didn't Rivera text first? Even a 30-second heads-up would help.
If Eli was unreachable, the exam crisis justifies the quick borrow.
